moves.1. d4 d6 2. e3 Nf6 3. f4: The Stonewall opening is an old stand-by. Provides exciting attacking chances. A very strong player, however, can refute it with a king's bishop fianchetto and a pawn thrust to e5. As an opening, it's a little bit  hoping the defense blitzes on first down. Works sometimes.
moves.4. Nf3 Bg4 5. Bd3 Bg7 6. Nbd2 O-O 7. c3: And black's next move should be e5, which will cause me all sorts of problems.
moves.8. f5: This is not a great gambit by white. I'll lose a pawn, and black can still get in a thrust at e5 later.
moves.8... c5: But apparently white doesn't want ruin his kingside paws. C5 is no trouble for white at all.
moves.9. O-O cxd4 10. exd4: Much better for white, freeing the dark bishop's potential.
moves.10... d5: Weak move for black. White has e4 well protected, and once the pin is removed by moving the queen, the knight might actually get to sit at e5.
moves.11. Qe1 Bxf3 12. Rxf3: Capturing with the knight removes a defender of e4 and allows the knight at f6 to hop in.
moves.12... Re8 13. fxg6 fxg6 14. Re3: Now an indecisive middle game. The hallmark of blitz chess!
moves.18... Kf7 19. Ne5+ Kf8: The pin on the knight at f6, given the newly opened file, is inspiring.
A blunder, but the knight would fall sooner or later with the rooks on the open f file.
moves.24. Bxf6 Bxf6 25. Qxf6 Qg7 26. Qxg7+: I can see trading the queens to blunt the attack, but the queen is now in a wide open shooting gallery with only the knight available to defend it.
moves.26... Kxg7 27. Rf1: Mating net begins. I mildly regret the retreat of the rook on the e file to the second rank. Should have come to the third, and this would go much more smoothly.
moves.30... Kh8: And this is why I annotated it. Right away, you see the knight mate.
